name: Yemen
currentCrisisSummary:
Yemen endures one of the world's most severe humanitarian catastrophes, directly caused by a protracted **proxy war** over state control and its **strategic position** on a key **global trade route**. The conflict, involving a **Saudi-led coalition** (backed by **Western arms**) and Iran-aligned forces, has been waged through **blockades**, **sieges**, and attacks on infrastructure, deliberately crippling the nation.

This violence and **externally imposed restrictions** have devastated the economy, wrecked public services, and produced **catastrophic hunger and disease**. Aid diversion further exacerbates civilian suffering. The crisis is actively sustained by **international arms flows**, **regional rivalries**, and **global economic interests** prioritising strategic gain over human life.

imperialRoot.imperialPower: Britain & Ottoman Empire (Aden 1839-1967; Ottoman presence in the north until 1918)
imperialRoot.legacy:
The crisis draws on deep **colonial-era divisions**. **British control** of Aden and the south, alongside **Ottoman administration** in the north, produced distinct legacies. Britain's patchwork of **protectorates** and **indirect rule** hindered unity and left a **governance vacuum**.

These **colonial partitions**, combined with later **Cold War geopolitics** and international economic policies, created fault-lines exploited by elites and **foreign powers**, contributing to cycles of conflict and **external intervention**.

historicalContext.title: Geopolitical Chokepoint and Global Trade
historicalContext.description: Yemen's geography astride the **Bab-el-Mandeb strait**, a vital **chokepoint** for **global trade** and energy, makes it a theatre for **strategic competition**. **Regional powers** and global actors seek influence over its coast and ports. Control of **maritime access** is a persistent objective for **external actors**.

historicalContext.title: Neoliberal Reforms and the Roots of Rebellion
historicalContext.description: Following unification, Yemen was subjected to **IMF/World Bank-led Structural Adjustment Programmes (SAPs)**. These **neoliberal "reforms"** mandated lifting subsidies, **privatisation**, and severe **austerity**. The resulting hardship disproportionately affected marginalised regions, feeding grievances of southern secessionists and the northern **Houthi rebellion**. The Houthi rise was partly a revolt against **corruption** and inequality from this **Western-backed economic model**.

historicalContext.title: The War on Terror and Foreign Intervention
historicalContext.description: The current war was preceded by years of **US intervention** under the "**Global War on Terror**". President Saleh exploited **US counter-terrorism aid** to acquire military funding used primarily against domestic opponents, including the **Houthis**. This use of an **imperial security framework** to crush dissent radicalised opposition. This was later supplanted by the current **proxy war**, sustained by large-scale **arms transfers** from Western nations to the **Saudi-led coalition**, enabling violations of **international law**.

historicalContext.title: International Law And Accountability
historicalContext.description: Allegations of unlawful attacks, **blockade-induced starvation**, and **aid diversion** prompt calls for **accountability**. UN bodies and rights organisations document potential **war crimes**. **Accountability** efforts remain politically contested but are central to justice and deterrence.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: Hundreds of thousands killed (est. 377k by late 2021) directly by **fighting or indirectly through conflict-induced starvation and disease.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population
humanitarianImpact.description: Roughly 19.5 million people require aid due to the **systematic destruction of the country by the warring parties and their international backers.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Food Insecurity
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 17 million face acute hunger, a direct result of **blockades, attacks on agriculture, and economic collapse caused by the war.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement
humanitarianImpact.description: Around 4.5 million internally displaced, forced from homes by **bombing campaigns, ground fighting, and climate shocks exacerbated by state failure.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugees
humanitarianImpact.description: Tens of thousands forced abroad by the **extreme violence and lack of basic survival conditions created by the conflict.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Healthcare Collapse
humanitarianImpact.description: Roughly half of health facilities non-functional due to **direct attacks, lack of supplies caused by blockades, and general infrastructure collapse.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Lack of Water Access
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 15 million lack safe water and sanitation due to **infrastructure destruction and import restrictions imposed by warring parties.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Education Denied
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 2 million children denied education as schools are **damaged by attacks or rendered inaccessible by displacement and conflict.**

timeline.event: **British seize Aden**: The British Empire captures the port of Aden, beginning a prolonged colonial presence in southern Yemen that would shape later regional divisions.
**Ottoman withdrawal & fragmented rule**: Ottoman influence in the north recedes after World War I; multiple sultanates, imamates and protectorates coexist until mid-20th century state formations.
**Unification**: North (Yemen Arab Republic) and South (People's Democratic Republic of Yemen) formally unite. Structural economic and political differences produce long-standing grievances.

**Civil War & Neoliberal Riots**: A short but bitter civil war deepens southern grievances. The conflict is exacerbated by widespread popular anger against IMF-mandated austerity measures imposed after unification.

**"War on Terror" & Houthi Uprising**: The US expands counter-terror operations, including drone strikes. The Saleh regime uses US military aid to suppress domestic opponents, particularly the nascent Houthi rebellion, which is also fuelled by anger at economic marginalisation.

**Houthi advance & coalition intervention**: Houthi forces seize large parts of the country, including Sana'a; a Saudi-led coalition launches an air and naval campaign and enforces blockades, precipitating the large-scale humanitarian catastrophe that follows.

**Protracted humanitarian catastrophe**: Years of siege, economic collapse, aid displacement and repeated attacks on infrastructure create a chronic humanitarian emergency that the UN repeatedly describes as among the worldâ€™s worst.

Delivers emergency food assistance and nutrition support to millions of people in Yemen; critical to preventing famine and treating severe malnutrition.
A Yemeni-led diaspora organisation providing direct aid, cash assistance and advocacy for reconstruction and peace.

advocacy: Demand an immediate end to blockades and sieges and insist on unimpeded, independent humanitarian access to all civilians.
Call on Western and regional governments to suspend arms transfers that enable indiscriminate attacks and to condition support on respect for international humanitarian law.
Support Yemeni-led peace initiatives and ensure that any diplomatic settlement protects civilians, restores services and addresses economic and political grievances.
Push for independent investigations into alleged war crimes and for accountability mechanisms that centre victims' rights and reparations.

reading.title: Destroying Yemen: What Chaos in Arabia Tells Us about the World
reading.description: Isa Blumi's critical history linking Yemen's modern conflicts to longer legacies of imperial intervention and regional power struggles.

reading.title: Yemen in Crisis: Autocracy, Neo-Liberalism and the Disintegration of a State
reading.description: Helen Lackner provides a detailed study of the political, social, and economic drivers, including neoliberal policies, that led to Yemen's current war.

reading.title: Yemen Endures: Civil War, Saudi Adventurism and the Future of Arabia
reading.description: Edited by Ginny Hill, et al. This collection (often cited similarly to your third entry) analyses governance failures, the impact of neoliberalism, and regional interventions contributing to state collapse.
